docs.lead_paragraph: Illegal, rarely prosecuted and rarely discussed, abortion has suddenly become a public issue in South Korea.

headline.main: South Korea Confronts Open Secret of Abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: Kaney O'Neill and David Trais will be in a Chicago courtroom this week, arguing over their five-month-old son, Aiden. Trais says that O'Neill is unfit to have custody of the boy because she is a quadriplegic, having lost all use of her legs and some use of her arms in a fall off a balcony a decade ago.

headline.main: Should a Quadriplegic Mom Have Custody?

docs.abstract: Kaney O'Neill and David Trais will be in a Chicago courtroom this week, arguing over their five-month-old son, Aiden. Trais says that O'Neill is unfit to have custody of the boy because she is a quadriplegic.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Democratic Congressional leaders work to merge the House and Senate versions of major health care legislation, a big question is what they will do about the Children's Health Insurance Program, which now provides coverage to more than nine million children and pregnant women and is expected to cover more than 14 million by 2013. The Senate bill would preserve the program, known as CHIP, and would extend federal financing through 2015, two years past its expiration date under current law. Two Democrats, Senators John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia and Bob Casey of Pennsylvania, fought hard to protect CHIP in the bill.

headline.main: Program for Children Has Uncertain Future
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS | MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Fate of Children's Health Insurance Program, which provides coverage to more than nine million children and pregnant women and is expected to cover more than 14 million by 2013, is unknown as Democratic Congressional leaders work to merge House and Senate versions of health care reform bill; Senate bill would preserve CHIP and extend federal financing through 2015 but House bill would end program and redirect recipients to other programs or insurance exchanges; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As Democratic Congressional leaders work to merge the House and Senate versions of major health care legislation, a big question is what they will do about the Children's Health Insurance Program, which now provides coverage to more than nine million...
